Description: [pronounceStart]Mąįrakere[pronounceEnd] is the primary tour in the Mapping [pronounceStart]Teejop[pronounceEnd] series, featuring Bascom and Observatory Hill. As such, it is meant to expose, orient, and “ground” students, faculty, staff, and visitors to the Ho-Chunk and Native history and presence of the University of Wisconsin. As a land grant institution, the University of Wisconsin has a deep history and complex history with the Ho-Chunk Nation, a history that has often been deliberately erased, ignored, and overlooked.
Starting: Begin outside South Hall, on Bascom Hill.
Accessibility: Tour route is paved but begins on a large hill
PhotoAlt: A view of Lake Mendota from the top of Observatory Hill on the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus. It is a clear day, and the lake is visible in the distance. In the foreground, the grassy hill slopes into a band of forest.

Description: Water guides visitors along the south shore of [pronounceStart]Tee Wąąkšik Homįk[pronounceEnd] (Lake Mendota) in the West Campus area, beginning at Dejope Residence Hall. Visitors will have an opportunity to explore the exterior and interior of Dejope Hall, before moving towards Willow Creek along the Lakeshore Nature Preserve Path.
Starting: Begin outside the east entrance of Dejope Hall.
Accessibility: Tour route is paved and mostly flat.
PhotoAlt: Dejope Residence Hall and the Lake Mendota shoreline are pictured in an aerial view of the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus during autumn on Oct. 14, 2023. The photograph was made from a helicopter looking northwest.
PhotoCaption: Photo by Althea Dotzour, retrieved from UW Photo Library

Description: Honor highlights the Camp Randall area of campus. While on this tour, visitors will consider the many paths that have long brought Indigenous peoples to Teejop, including diplomacy, trade, and sport.
Starting: Begin at the entrance to Ho-Chunk Nation Plaza, on the northwest corner of Camp Randall.
Accessibility: Tour route is paved and flat.
PhotoAlt: The Camp Randall Memorial Arch at the University of Wisconsin-Madison is pictured during summer on June 20, 2016. The arch is in the center of the photo, and is made from light-gray stone. A brick path goes beneath the arch. Trees and flowers surround the arch.
PhotoCaption: Photo by Jeff Miller, retrieved from UW Photo Library

Description: Trails highlights the central area of campus. While on this tour, visitors will consider the many paths that have long brought Indigenous peoples to Teejop, including diplomacy, trade, and sport.
Starting: Begin at the entrance to Allen Centennial Garden.
Accessibility: Tour route is paved, and mostly flat.
PhotoAlt: A bed of small, purple flowers at the Allen Centennial Garden at UW-Madison. The flowers have five petals and are interspered with small, green leaves.
PhotoCaption: Photo by Hyunsoo Leo Kim, retrieved from UW Photo Library

Description: Gathering Place, an extended tour, guides visitors through some of the most notable buildings of the central campus area, beginning at the Memorial Union, and including the Historical Society, the Chazen Museum. Visitors will have an opportunity to reflect on how American Indian people have contributed to the University of Wisconsin in important ways—spanning scholarship to advocacy to art.
PhotoAlt: A front view of the University of Wisconsin-Madison Memorial Union. The building is made of multicolored brown and beige bricks rising two to three stories high at different points. The main entrance is located behind a row of small columns.

Description: Choose this option if you wish to explore Native and Ho-Chunk sites on campus in any order.
PhotoAlt: An aerial photograph of the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus, oriented so that north is at the top of the image. Lake Mendota is visible in the upper third of the image, while campus buildings comprise much of the middle of the image, while a residential area is present in the lower left.
